p.seg: This letter [i.e. original version of 90-09-13] consists of three sheets. The sheet beginning with Es wurde wichtig is numbered 5 and so possibly belongs with the dated and signed sheet or another long letter with more than four pages. The sheet beginning with In Bezug auf Livistonia is not numbered and could go with any letter.
There are no marginal additions to any sheet with the exception of the signed and dated sheet which has a clear marginal insertion in the text.
You two will have to sort it out from the context of what is written as I've proofed all three sheets.
For the purpose of finding the sheets again in the files, the two undated sheets are with the signed and dated sheet.
I suspect the only way to sort out the Holtze mess would be to go to SA and look at the originals to match up folds in the sheets and so on and even then it might not be possible.

div.p: GRG 19/391, State Records of South Australia, Adelaide.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: Sheet labelled 5, that is the fifth page. It is added here on that basis, consistent with the content that continues the discussion of Livistona.

p.seg: Es würde wichtig sein, gute Blätter, Blüthen u reife Früchte Ihrer beiden Livistona Arten zu erlangen. Ich würde dann mein ganzes Material hier nochmals im Vergleich mit solchen Zugaben von Ihnen durcharbeiten von Neuem. In R Brown's ursprünglichen Notizen mag auch Confusion sein.

Früher unterschied ich Hypoestes floribunda u. H. laxiflora Nees. Es scheinen aber Übergänge vorzukommen. Vielleicht habe ich aber eine gute 2te Art von dort nicht erkannt bei flüchtiger Ansicht. Hat Ihre H. moschata einen besonderen Moschus-Geruch? Woher haben Sie diesen Species-Namen?

Ich habe den Namen Cochlospermum heteronemum zu Gunsten von C. Fraseri unterdrückt. Letztere ist von Planchon als von der Melville-Insel beschrieben aber nur nach Blumen u ohne Blätter u Früchte. Planchon giebt die unregelmässige Länge der Stamina v. C. heteronemum bei seiner C. Fraseri nicht an, Bentham freilich übersah dies auch, trotzt

p.style: font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;
p.seg: trotz?

meiner vorherigen genauen Beschreibung. Ich nehme an, dass sich dies in Arnhem's Land gewöhnliche C. heteronemum in die Melville Insel erstreckt; oder haben Sie dort noch eine besondere Art beobachtet? Planchon beschreibt die Blüthenstiele und die Kelche (Sepala) von C. Fraseri als filzig. Würde dies ein constanter Character sein? Wieviel Arten unterscheiden
dort? u Ihr Sohn. Ich habe noch nie ein Ex. des Cochlospermum Fraseri ächt

p.style: font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

p.seg: gesehen oder zuverlässig. Daher muss vielleicht C. heteronema wieder hergestellt werden.
Ich gebe mich der angenehmen Hoffnung hin, dass Sie Mr O'Reilley am Staaten River einen Besuch abstellen können um seine Gegend für Ihren Garten auszubeuten.
Bei den Pollen-Massen der Orchideen handelt es sich nicht nur um die Zahl, Consistenz u Form, sondern auch um die Weise der Anhaftung oder Befestigung.
It would be important to obtain good leaves, flowers and ripe fruits of your two
Livistona
species.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: See also M to M. Holtze, 27 October 1883, no. 332, and M. Holtze to M, 16 March 1892 (in this edition as 92-03-16a).

p.seg: I would then work once more through all of my material here in comparison with such additions from you. There might also be confusion in Robert Brown's original notes.
Formerly I differentiated
Hypoestes floribunda
from
H. laxiflora
Nees. However, there appear to occur transitional forms. But perhaps I did not recognise a second good species from there during a cursory scanning. Does your
H. moschata
have a pronounced musk smell? From where do you have this species name?

p.style: font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: See also M to M. Holtze, 26 October 1883 (in this edition as 83-10-26a), no. 295.

p.seg: I have suppressed the name
Cochlospermum heteronemum
in favour of
C. fraseri

p.style: font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: M does not list C. heteronemum in B89.12.03, although he had included it (no. 232) in an 1883 list of identifications for Holtze (in this edition as 83-00-00l), and listed both it and C. fraseri in B83.03.04.

p.seg: The latter was described by Planchon

p.style: font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

p.seg: from Melville Island,

p.style: font-family: Geneva, 'Segoe UI Symbol'; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

p.seg: but from flowers only, and without leaves and fruit. Planchon does not mention the uneven length of the stamens in
C. heteronemum
for his
C. fraseri
, Bentham of course also overlooked this, in spite of my previous precise description. I assume that
C. heteronemum
, common in Arnhem Land, extends also to Melville Island; or have you observed a separate species there? Planchon described the pedicels and the calices (sepals) of
C. fraseri
as downy. Would this be a constant character? How many species do
differentiate there? And your son. I have never yet seen a genuine specimen of
Cochlospermum fraseri
, or at least not reliably so. Consequently
C. heteronemum
should perhaps be restored.
I indulge myself with the pleasant hope that you will be able to visit Mr O'Reilley at the Staaten River, to exploit his area for your Garden.
